trans-unit.source: It’s impossible to talk about +DHIS2 without mentioning the +HISP program and HISP groups.
But what +exactly is a HISP group, and how do they work with DHIS2? In this video, we will provide an overview.
HISP and the origins of DHIS2

Let’s start with the original +Health Information Systems <tx>Programme</tx>, or +HISP, which developed version 1 of the +DHIS software in post-Apartheid South Africa in 1994 as a +collaboration between the University of Oslo and the University of the Western Cape.

HISP has since become a +global movement to strengthen Health Information Systems world-wide, as DHIS2 experts--many of whom are former <tx>UiO</tx> PhD students--have gone on to found and lead HISP groups in Africa, Asia and the Americas.

These HISP groups offer long-term +support to country governments on DHIS2 +implementation and maintenance, provide +capacity-building through the DHIS2 Academy program, and work with countries and organizations to adapt +DHIS2 systems and create +innovative solutions to meet local needs.

HISP groups--together with HISP +<tx>UiO</tx>--form a global network of partners that shares common values, including +open source principles, +local ownership, +sustainability, +transparency, and +empowering data use.
While each group operates independently, the HISP network as a whole collaborates in a variety of ways.
Action research, assessment and information sharing

In keeping with <tx>DHIS2’s +academic </tx><tx>origins, a primary area </tx><tx>of +HISP </tx><tx>collaboration is research. </tx><tx>Working +with </tx><tx>the Information Systems research group at HISP </tx><tx>UiO</tx>, HISP groups engage in +action research, uncovering +best practices through targeted country interventions and deep dives. They +assess and evaluate country DHIS2 implementations, +explore new domains and challenges, and +document their findings for input into global products and strategies.

Another key area of collaboration is <tx>the +ongoing </tx><tx>development of </tx><tx>the DHIS2 </tx><tx>platform. While +software development is led by HISP </tx><tx>UiO</tx><tx>, the HISP groups are the most important source of +requirements for software features </tx><tx>and +field </tx><tx>testing of DHIS2 +releases, due to their close work with country governments. </tx><tx>Their +input </tx><tx>and feedback </tx><tx>is essential </tx>to ensuring that DHIS2 continues to meet local needs and function in local contexts.

HISP groups are also <tx>a +source of local innovations</tx><tx>, such </tx><tx>as +custom </tx><tx>applications</tx><tx>, +metadata </tx><tx>configurations, </tx><tx>and +modifications </tx><tx>to the core platform, developed to rapidly solve specific country challenges. These local solutions </tx><tx>are +shared </tx><tx>throughout the network and can be adapted by +the core team at HISP </tx><tx>UiO</tx><tx> for global deployment, followed </tx><tx>by +iterative </tx><tx>improvements based on </tx><tx>further feedback </tx>from HISP groups based on real-world experiences.
Example: global resource based on local innovation
One example of a +local innovation becoming a +global resource was the +HISP network’s response to the +COVID-19 pandemic, where a DHIS2 program for port of entry screening and contact tracing
developed by +HISP Sri Lanka became the basis for a +metadata package quickly deployed in +almost 40 countries for the COVID-19 response.

+HISP groups also work together in regional hubs on +national, +multi-country and +regional DHIS2 +system architecture, +implementation, +research and +capacity building <tx>projects +in </tx><tx>collaboration with HISP </tx><tx>UiO</tx>

In addition to this cycle <tx>of collaboration between HISP </tx><tx>groups in the field and HISP </tx><tx>UiO</tx><tx>, +individual </tx><tx>members from </tx><tx>various HISP </tx><tx>groups also serve as +members of core DHIS2 teams, where they directly contribute </tx><tx>to development of +global </tx>metadata packages, +applications, and +training materials.
The origin of the DHIS software
The driving force in developing DHIS2
Provide input and feedback on DHIS2 software
Ensure that DHIS2 meets local needs

The HISP project <tx>, was +the </tx><tx>origin of the DHIS software, </tx><tx>and HISP </tx><tx>groups have </tx><tx>been +the </tx><tx>driving force in developing DHIS2 from a local solution </tx><tx>into the </tx><tx>world’s largest health information management system. </tx><tx>They +provide long-term </tx><tx>implementation and maintenance support</tx><tx>, +conduct </tx><tx>capacity-building</tx><tx>, +perform </tx><tx>information system research and assessment, +provide input and feedback on software releases</tx><tx>, +develop </tx><tx>and share local innovations, </tx><tx>and +ensure </tx>that DHIS2 continues to meet local needs.
HISP <tx>groups are not just </tx><tx>a +part </tx>of the DHIS2 story--they are the foundation of DHIS2’s history. Without the HISP groups, there would be no DHIS2.
